step.dialogue: Not quite. Think about how the [vocab]denominator[/vocab] affects the size of each piece.

Let's think about this together. When we have unit fractions like these, the [vocab]denominator[/vocab] tells us how many equal parts make up the whole. The smaller the [vocab]denominator[/vocab], the fewer parts we're dividing into, which means each part is bigger. Compare [fraction numerator=1 denominator=3]one third[/fraction] and [fraction numerator=1 denominator=7]one seventh[/fraction] - which has the smaller [vocab]denominator[/vocab]?

Let me walk you through comparing unit fractions. When we compare [fraction numerator=1 denominator=3]one third[/fraction], [fraction numerator=1 denominator=5]one fifth[/fraction], and [fraction numerator=1 denominator=7]one seventh[/fraction], we need to think about what each [vocab]denominator[/vocab] means. [vocab]One-[/vocab][vocab]third[/vocab] means we divide something into 3 equal parts - those are fairly large pieces. [vocab]One-[/vocab][vocab]fifth[/vocab] means 5 equal parts - smaller pieces. [vocab]One-[/vocab]seventh means 7 equal parts - even smaller pieces. So the pattern is: the smaller the [vocab]denominator[/vocab], the bigger the piece. That means [fraction numerator=1 denominator=3]one third[/fraction] is the largest, then [fraction numerator=1 denominator=5]one fifth[/fraction], then [fraction numerator=1 denominator=7]one seventh[/fraction]. The correct order from largest to smallest is [fraction numerator=1 denominator=3]one third[/fraction], [fraction numerator=1 denominator=5]one fifth[/fraction], [fraction numerator=1 denominator=7]one seventh[/fraction]. That's how unit fractions work - smaller denominators make bigger pieces.

on_correct.dialogue: Right. Smaller [vocab]denominator[/vocab] means bigger piece.
